Description: A hollow terracotta head broken from a figure of a female saint or beneficent demon, with a triangular wreath framing her hair. There are holes pierced at ear level and at the top of the hair. The rear is lost. Two-piece mould. Orange Aswan kaolinite clay with a yellow slip overall. There are details in fired-on black and red-brown ceramic colours, including large round pendent earrings and a pendant at the throat in the form of a circle with a cross within.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired at Elephantine. Late Roman, sixth to seventh century AD. Comparanda: Near: Mond and Myers 1940: pls xxvi:P 36 and lxix:1, from Armant; Duncan 1906: pl. xlii:19 (head only), from a late Roman grave at Gheyta, north-east of Tell el-Yahudiyeh in the eastern Delta; Roeder 1959: pl. 560, from Hermopolis Magna.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3398)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
